1.heading: Doonesberries.
1.title: "That's Not Caviar, They're Ground Doonesberries"
1.author: by Bobby London (San Francisco, Calif
1.series: Dirty Duck) 1 p. in The Dirty Duck Book

2.heading: Doonesbury, Michael.
2.title: "Mike's Annual Summer Daydream is Under Way"
2.author: Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Bernie wants Mike to move to Seattle, telecommute, wear flannel shirts, and start at $300,000.
Strip originally appeared July 25, 1995.

3.title: Doonesbury
3.author: by G
3.appears_in: B. Trudeau ; forword by Erich Segal.

publication info.publisher: ill. ; 17 x 19 cm. I. Trudeau, G. B.
ill. ; 16 x 18 cm. I. Trudeau, G. B.

5.title: Doonesbury : a musical comedy
5.author: book and lyrics by G
5.appears_in: B. Trudeau ; music by Elizabeth Swados.
notes: Libretto. 1. Musicals
Librettos. I. Swados, Elizabeth. II. Trudeau, G. B., 1948- Call no.: ML50.S9806D6 1984

6.title: "Doonesbury : l'Amerique sans Fard"
6.author: par Jean-Paul Jennequin
6.appears_in: p. 60-65 in Les Cahiers de la Bande Dessinée, no. 80 (Mar. 1988).
notes: Article on Doonesbury.

7.title: Doonesbury : Life Visits Garry Trudeau's Walden as His Comic Strip Reappears
7.author: illustrations and text by Garry Trudeau
notes: Cover title: Doonesbury is Back!

8.heading: Doonesbury.
8.title: The American Cancer Society vs. Mr. Butts : The Great Smoking Debate.
8.author: [No author]
notes: American Cancer Society, 199-?.
Illustrations are of the Doonesbury character, Mr. Butts, by G.B. Trudeau.
Topic: Cigarette habit.
Genre: Educational.

9.heading: Doonesbury.
9.title: Hart Breaking.
9.author: [No author]
notes: (Little Brother Press Publication ; no. 210)
For CAPA-alpha no. 272 and Interlac no. 67.
Political essay about Sen. Gary Hart, illustrated with Doonesbury strips.

10.heading: Doonesbury.
10.title: "It Has a Familiar Ring to It: Driving While Brown"
10.author: by Gretchen Cochran
10.appears_in: p. 5-6 in the Lansing City Pulse, July 11, 2007.
notes: Article on Mexican Americans, illustrated with a Doonesbury strip.

11.title: Doonesbury The Sunday Comics : half-sheets and smaller : locally assembled collection.
11.author: [No author]
notes: 20th century dates.

Clipped Sunday strips, half-sheet and tabloid size or smaller, collected in the Michigan State University Libraries' Russel B. Nye Popular Culture Collection. Strips are represented by a few examples each.

12.heading: Doonesbury.
12.title: Why Marijuana Should Be Legal
12.author: Ed Rosenthal and Steve Kubby.
notes: Includes bibliographical references (p. 107-118).
Includes illustrations from Doonesbury comics by Gary Trudeau.

14.heading: Doonesbury. Danish.
14.title: Det her måvoere mit livs voerste tømmermoend
14.author: G
14.appears_in: B. Trudeau ; på dansk ved Per Vadmand.
notes: (Doonesbury ; 8)
Translation of: Death of a Party Animal.

15.heading: Doonesbury. Danish.
15.title: Doonesbury et Forbandet Snedigt Folkefærd
15.author: G
15.appears_in: B. Trudeau ; på dansk ved Ole Steen Hansen og Michael Enné ; redaktion, Jens Peder Agger.
notes: (Doonesbury ; 2)
Doonesbury in Danish.

16.title: Doonesbury
16.author: G
16.series: Sept. 9, 1976) "She Even Got Fifty Cents Out of One of Them!"*
notes: Summary: Mr. Sutton has met the scamp at the lemonade stand.

17.title: Doonesbury
17.author: G
17.series: July 11, 1980) "I Just Hope I Don't Embarrass Sonny"*
17.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reproduced on p. 128 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Zonker selects his tan for the Gerald R. Ford Summer Biathlon (a golf suntan tournament): Sonny Bono's "Freeway Bold."

18.title: Doonesbury
18.author: G
18.series: July 12, 1980) "Let's Try a Seven Iron and a #2 Sun Screen"*
18.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reproduced on p. 128 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The Gerald R. Ford Summer Biathlon continues.

19.title: Doonesbury
19.author: G
19.series: July 15, 1980) "The Kid Was Hotdogging. He Knew the Risks"*
19.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reproduced on p. 129 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: One of the competitors in the Gerald R. Ford Summer Biathlon gets sunstroke.

20.title: Doonesbury
20.author: G
20.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reproduced on p. 129 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Zonker wins the tanning award, and thanks George Hamilton and all the little people who've supported him. Mark and B.D. don't particularly like being called little people.

21.title: Doonesbury
21.author: G
21.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reprinted on p. 41 of Mother Jones, v. 6, no. 2 (Feb./Mar. 1981)
notes: Summary: Roland Hedley introduces his voyage into the brain of Ronald Reagan.

22.title: Doonesbury
22.author: G
22.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reprinted on p. 41 of Mother Jones, v. 6, no. 2 (Feb./Mar. 1981)
notes: Summary: Hedley begins the tour of the brain of Ronald Reagan, talking about 5-cent Cokes, Burma Shave signs, Angola, Iran, Korea, Cyprus, Cuba, Lebanon, and using terminology like fornix, hypothalamus, and marbles.

23.title: Doonesbury
23.author: G
23.series: Oct. 29, 1980) "Mr. Reagan's Ability to Reconcile Huge Tax Cuts with Massive Military Spending Must Be Viewed with Some Sympathy"*
23.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reprinted on p. 42 of Mother Jones, v. 6, no. 2 (Feb./Mar. 1981)
notes: Summary: Hedley points out the results of sleep deprivation on Reagan's cerebrum, usually charged with logic and critical thinking but now compensating with hallucination.

24.title: Doonesbury
24.author: G
24.series: Oct. 30, 1980) "The Brain of Ronald Reagan has been Shrinking Ever Since 1931"*
24.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reprinted on p. 42 of Mother Jones, v. 6, no. 2 (Feb./Mar. 1981)
notes: Summary: Roland Hedley is in the cerebellum, and mentions that the brain stops growing at age 20.

25.title: Doonesbury
25.author: G
25.series: Oct. 31, 1980) "Instead of Looking Forward Through Clear Eyes, Reagan is Only Able to See Backwards Through a Rose-Colored Mist"*
25.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reprinted on p. 42 of Mother Jones, v. 6, no. 2 (Feb./Mar. 1981)
notes: Summary: Hedley visits the visual cortex in Ronald Reagan's brain.

26.title: Doonesbury
26.author: G
26.series: Nov. 1, 1980) "Our Political Folklore is the Richer for it"*
26.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reprinted on p. 42 of Mother Jones, v. 6, no. 2 (Feb./Mar. 1981)
notes: Summary: The path of Ronald Reagan's subconscious thoughts towards utterance is found to involve an end run around full consciousness, explaining things he has said about tree pollution and the Ku-Klux Klan.

27.title: Doonesbury
27.author: Garry Trudeau
notes: Summary: Honey Wakes Duke for his Inauguration day Swearing-In and Speech.

28.title: Doonesbury
28.author: G
28.series: Apr. 9, 1985) "First Day In, I'm Sent to Grenada"*
notes: Summary: The Vietnam vets are still bitter about how they were treated when they got home, but Willie got a parade after invading a golf course on Grenada.

29.title: Doonesbury
29.author: by Garry B
29.series: May 12, 1985) "Anyone Know What I Majored In?"*
notes: Summary: The graduation speaker finishes his address, and snaps his fingers to awaken the class from its four-year trance.

30.title: Doonesbury
30.author: by Garry Trudeau.
30.series: May 13, 1985) "The Cops Closed the Hydrants Again"*
notes: Summary: Rick Redfern gets a visit at his office from Alice, who apologizes for the way she smells.

31.title: Doonesbury
31.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Alice tells Rick she's found a compatible fellow vagrant to marry.

32.title: Doonesbury
32.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Alice introduces Rick Redfern to Elmont.

33.title: Doonesbury
33.author: by Garry Trudeau.
33.series: May 17, 1985) "I Met Her Dumpster-Diving Behind Trader Vic's"*
notes: Summary: Elmont and Alice talk about how they met; Elmont uses the occasion to decry wasteful military spending.

34.title: Doonesbury
34.author: by Garry Trudeau.
34.series: May 18, 1985) "Psst! Your Grace! Do You Do Weddings?"*
notes: Summary: Alice has gone to a demonstration at the South African embassy, hoping to find a priest.

35.title: Doonesbury
35.author: by Garry Trudeau.
35.series: Apr. 9, 1986) "Pass. We're Not Talking Mother Teresa Here"*
notes: Summary: Zonker says he won't pay a $10 million finder's fee for Duke's return.

36.title: Doonesbury
36.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Clyde visits. He lost his "hip angry pose" to Dale Carnegie, and is opening a local branch store.

37.title: Doonesbury
37.author: G
37.series: Nov. 14, 1986) "For the Next Minute, in an Ornithologists' Salute, we will all Perform our Favorite Bird Calls"*
notes: Summary: A funeral for the president of the Maryland Audubon Society.

38.title: Doonesbury
38.author: G
notes: Key words: Sex education, precautions, parents.

39.title: Doonesbury
39.author: G
39.series: June 2, 1987) "We Think He Must Have Walked Through a Metal Detector"*
notes: Summary: Hedley dedicates his testimony to his cameraman, who died in the President's brain during a sudden brainstorm.
Call no> PN6726 f.B55 "brainstorms"

contents.author: G.B. Trudeau.
contents.title: Doonesbury (June 5, 1987) "Did It Ever Occur to You that a Massive Explosion Inside Mr. Reagan's Brain might Adversely Affect his Subsequent Mental Performance?"* (Doonesbury, June 5, 1987)

notes: Summary: Roland Hedley is testifying at a hearing about hurling an incendiary device at the President's fornix.

41.title: Doonesbury
41.author: G
notes: Summary: The warden wants to have a talk with Phil.

42.title: Doonesbury
42.author: G
42.series: Feb. 20, 1988) "Prince Albert Hated the Humbler-than-Thou Segments of the Debates"*
notes: Summary: Al Gore listens to other candidates talk about log cabins and eating bark, but later in a specially handicapped event he says his daddy made him shovel pig manure.

43.title: Doonesbury
43.author: G
43.series: Mar. 25, 1988) "And Dad, Bring Lots of Tweeds!"*
notes: Summary: Zonker takes a hint, and invites his family to move into the estate.
Setting: Playing croquet.

44.title: Doonesbury
44.author: GB Trudeau.
44.series: Aug. 18, 1988) "This is My Dad's 25-Year-Old Golf Cart"*
notes: Summary: George Bush's son is introducing him using a slide show.

45.title: Doonesbury
45.author: by Garry Trudeau.
45.series: Sept. 28, 1988) "Apparently the Switch Was Made in New Orleans, Shortly After Bush's Disastrous Selection of Dan Quayle as His Running Mate"*
notes: Summary: The public George Bush is now being played by his evil twin Skippy Bush.

46.title: Doonesbury
46.author: G
46.series: Nov. 16, 1988) "I Thought I Went to Harvard"*
notes: Summary: Mike has a job doing recruitment for Walden College, because their image is so bad Zonker can't even remember that he went there.

47.title: Doonesbury
47.author: by Garry Trudeau.
47.series: Jan. 24, 1989) "I Thought it Was Dental Floss"*
notes: Summary: Boopsie can't find the swimsuit, but it's in her hand.
Key words: Sun block, hair streaks, sun bleaching, shoots, clipboards.

48.title: Doonesbury
48.author: G
48.series: June 22, 1989) "Apparently I'm Well Enough to Croak at Home"*
notes: Summary: Andrew returns from the hospital to find Mrs. Pocatelli hasn't rented his apartment.

49.title: Doonesbury
49.author: Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Chinese undergraduates are singing This Land is Your Land at the foot of the Statue of Liberty.

50.title: Doonesbury
50.author: G
50.series: Apr. 3, 1990) "The Male Yak Approaches His Mate Cautiously"*
notes: Summary: The census form will have to wait until Elmont finishes the wildlife special.

51.title: Doonesbury
51.author: G
51.series: Apr. 4, 1990) "Wrong! I Knew Both my Parents!"*
notes: Suummary: Elmont has filled out the census form, though we don't know how since he's illiterate.

52.title: Doonesbury
52.author: G
52.series: Apr. 7, 1990) "What Makes Them So Special? Have They Done Letterman?"*
notes: Summary: The census taker is trying to count the homeless, and Elmont wants to know about the helpless, the rootless, the toothless, the young, and the restless.

53.title: Doonesbury
53.author: G
notes: Summary: Boopsie is worried how hurt and threatened B.D. is going to be when he finds out what she's done.

54.title: Doonesbury
54.author: G
54.series: Aug. 17, 1991) "Well, You Didn't Have to Keep the Motor Running!"*
notes: Summary: Boopsie sends B.D. packing, and he comes back to the car with his suitcase and golf clubs.

55.title: Doonesbury
55.author: G
notes: Summary: Zonker's life summarized. Trip to the emergency room, first day of school, leaving home, and moving back in.

56.title: Doonesbury
56.author: G
56.series: Oct. 9, 1991) "So Is That a Bleach Job, or What?"*
notes: Summary: B.D. goes on about football, until Boopsie tries to get him to change the subject.

57.title: Doonesbury
57.author: G
57.series: Nov. 26, 1991) "I Was Told We Were Going to Talk About Golf"*
notes: Summary: Dan Quayle doesn't want the interview to be about the DEA, Brett Kimberlin, and political damage control.

58.title: Doonesbury
58.author: [No author]
58.series: Feb. 24, 1992) "My Cache of Selective Service Memorabilia"*
notes: Summary: Zonker finds his old panty hose in a box.

59.title: Doonesbury
59.author: G
59.series: June 8, 1992) "This is NPR, and You're Tuned to Lite 'n' Easy Rock!"*
notes: Summary: Mark plays the Kinks.

60.title: Doonesbury
60.author: G
60.series: June 19, 1992) "Passive Smokers Really Bring Their Problems on Themselves, by Being Passive"*
notes: Summary: Mr. Butts is testifying before Congresswoman Davenport.

61.title: Doonesbury
61.author: G
61.series: Jan. 11, 1993) "We Would Never Compromise the Pacing and Structure of a Plot Line Just to Comment on Some Topical Event"*

62.title: Doonesbury
62.author: G
notes: Summary: Joanie's starting her new job at the Justice Department, and talks about a former classmate named Woodrow.

63.title: Doonesbury
63.author: G
63.series: Mar. 10, 1993) "We're Trying to Save a Way of Life Here"*
notes: Summary: Mr. Brewski, Mr Butts and Mr. Dum-Dum meet in Washington to lobby against sin taxes and the Brady Bill (gun control).

64.title: Doonesbury
64.author: by Garry Trudeau.
64.series: June 17, 1993) "B.D., Do You Realize Our Lives are Peaking Tonight?"*
notes: Summary: Boopsie and B.D. are in a limo on the way to see the President, while the President has his people cancelling the visit and sending an autographed picture. Boopsie is in a $3,000 dress.

65.title: Doonesbury
65.author: by Garry Trudeau.
65.series: Sept. 11, 1993) "It's Much Hipper to be Lesbian"*
notes: Summary: Mark is staying with J.J. and Mike during his coming out, and J.J. offers to take him to hang out with her gay friends; Mike says not to rush him, and J.J. says she thought she was a lesbian a few years ago.

66.title: Doonesbury
66.author: by Garry Trudeau.
66.series: Dec. 6, 1993) "Can Confirm 'Cigarette Holder Man' is Ex-Ambassador Duke'"
notes: Summary: A JFK assassination conspiracy researcher has found a photograph that Duke doctored himself into in 1967 to raise money.

67.title: Doonesbury
67.author: by Garry Trudeau.
67.series: May 7, 1994) "Honey, Promise Me You'll See a Specialist"*
notes: Summary: Mark tries to describe the difficulties of coming out to his mom, hoping she'll try to understand.

68.title: Doonesbury
68.author: by Garry Trudeau.
68.series: Mar. 21, 1994) "Off to Capitol Hill to Put Out Another Fire"*
notes: Summary: Mr. Butts sometimes feels the world is against him, but he perks up when he thinks about all the smokers who still need him.

69.title: Doonesbury
69.author: G
69.series: Apr. 19, 1993) "Dodging Bullets on the Sinai, Slogging Through the Delta, Sweating out Air Raids in Baghdad"*
notes: Summary: Ambassador Duke and journalist Hedley compare notes about tight spots, and both are motivated by audience share.

70.title: Doonesbury
70.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Joanie Caucus has gone to see Josh Lyman, the "White House deputy cabinet liaison," who's playing darts in his office and looks very young.

71.title: Doonesbury
71.author: by Garry Trudeau.
71.series: June 8, 1994) "Oh, Well, Sure, Catholics. They Have a Ritual for Everything"*
notes: Summary: Mark talks about the sin of homosexuality with a fundamentalist Christian, and says the church sanctioned gay marriage for 1,000 years.

72.title: Doonesbury
72.author: by Garry Trudeau.
72.series: June 10, 1994) "And We'll Have More on 14th-Century Queers Right After This!"*
notes: Summary: Mark is on the air talking about the church and gays in the dark ages.

73.title: Doonesbury
73.author: G
73.series: June 13, 1994) "My Own Wife is a Woman"*
notes: Summary: Mark is interviewing Dan Quayle on the air, about same-sex marriages.

74.title: Doonesbury
74.author: Garry Trudeau.
74.series: July 25, 1995) "Mike's Annual Summer Daydream is Under Way"*
notes: Summary: Bernie wants Mike to move to Seattle, telecommute, wear flannel shirts, and start at $300,000.
Strip originally appeared July 25, 1995.

75.title: Doonesbury
75.author: G
75.series: Oct. 25, 1996) "The Widow's Walk- There's Loads of Room"*
notes: Summary: Millie has to decide where to grow her medicinal marijuana.

76.title: Doonesbury
76.author: G
76.series: Jan. 9, 1997) "It Was Thought to Be Too Derivative"*
notes: Summary: Glimpse of an early version of Doonesbury shows Zonker in Charlie Brown's clothes on his back on top of a doghouse.

77.title: Doonesbury
77.author: G
notes: Summary: The President prepares to sign an order combining midnight basketball and vaccination programs.

78.title: Doonesbury
78.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Kim borrows Mike's daydream to promote social justice, and convinces Michael Jordan to give back Nike's money.
Key words: Endorsement contracts.

79.title: Doonesbury
79.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Michael Jordan proposes to rebuke Nike, so they will start being responsible abroad.
Key words: Endorsement contracts.

80.title: Doonesbury
80.author: G
notes: Summary: Michael Jordan thanks Kim for reminding him that in his position he can make a difference; Tiger Woods calls.
Key words: Phone calls, endorsement contracts.

81.title: Doonesbury
81.author: G
81.series: July 31, 1997) "I Can't Just Say Ethics Aren't My Department"*
notes: Summary: Kim has taught Tiger Woods that he has to take a stand on Nike and manufacturing conditions abroad, and he calls her a warrior.
Key words: Golf, endorsement contracts.

82.title: Doonesbury
82.author: G
notes: Summary: Wearing a Reebok hat, Tiger Woods dissociates himself from Nike, and regrets not meeting Kim before she married.
Key word Nightmares, endorsement contracts.

83.title: Doonesbury
83.author: G
notes: Summary: Kim talks with Lisa Leslie of the L.A. Sparks (WNBA), about returning Nike's money.
Key words: Endorsement contracts, women's basketball.

84.title: Doonesbury
84.author: G
84.series: Nov. 4, 1997) "Either Heroin Addiction or Something About Personal Grooming"*
notes: Summary: The governor has appointed Clyde to replace Lacey; she remembers he once accused her of something.

85.title: Doonesbury
85.author: G
85.series: Jan. 22, 1998) "So What's Wrong With My Golf Idea?"*
notes: Summary: Phred is going to take Michael Jordan golfing instead of showing him the worker conditions in the Nike plant.

86.title: Doonesbury
86.author: by G
86.series: Aug. 17, 1998) "Like the Hippie-Rebel Dudes of Yore!"*
notes: Summary: Mark interviews a Michigan State University student about the Spring beer riots at MSU, who insists that the dismantling of the fundamental right to party has sparked a pro-binge movement.

87.title: Doonesbury
87.author: G
notes: Summary: Elmont rages against real estate agents, calling them bloodsuckers and sharks, but then sees a picture of a cute one.

88.title: Doonesbury
88.author: G
88.series: June 17, 1999) "If You Go Ahead with this Lunacy, my Entire Estate is Going to the Animal Society"*
notes: Summary: The estate is $75 million; Mark calls Chase with second thoughts about their wedding ceremony.

89.title: Doonesbury
89.author: by Garry Trudeau.
89.series: July 15, 1999) "We Had the Hanoi Gay Men's Glee Club, but They Bailed"*
notes: Summary: Phred and Jimmy discuss their Saigon concert.

90.title: Doonesbury
90.author: G
90.series: Feb. 16, 2000) "Do You Think that Other Symbols of Official Racism, like Segregation and Discrimination, Should Have Been Left Up to the People of South Carolina?"*
notes: Summary: Duke defends his position on the confederate flag.

91.title: Doonesbury
91.author: G
91.series: Feb. 17, 2000) "What Are You Doing Here? This is the Republican Primary"*
notes: Summary: Duke defends his position on the confederate flag.

92.title: Doonesbury
92.author: by Garry Trudeau.
92.series: Feb. 18, 2000) "Racists? You Mean Proud Heritage Buffs?"*
notes: Summary: Duke struggles with the issue of the confederate flag, which both Bush and McCain have ducked.

93.title: Doonesbury
93.author: G
93.series: Feb. 19, 2000) "I Won't Condemn it as a Symbol of Racism, I'll Condemn It as a Symbol of Losing!"*
notes: Summary: Duke struggles with the issue of the confederate flag.

94.title: Doonesbury
94.author: G
94.series: Apr. 4, 2000) "I'm Guessing Some Little Girl is on the Patch!"*
notes: Summary: Mr. Butts wants to sponsor Duke's campaign, and Honey finds that intolerable.

95.title: Doonesbury
95.author: G
95.series: Aug. 8, 2000) "In Long Beach, Team Duke Plans a Daring Caper"
notes: Summary: Duke's going to sneak in and give a speech at the convention.

96.title: Doonesbury
96.author: G
96.series: Oct. 6, 2000) "He's Trying To Make Me Look Ridiculistic, Isn't He?"*
notes: Summary: Governor George W. Bush learns about Duke's challenge to a pronunciation bee.

97.title: Doonesbury
97.author: G
notes: Summary: George W. Bush won't accept Duke's pronunciation challenge.

98.title: Doonesbury
98.author: G
98.series: Oct. 13, 2000) "Even His Big Kiss with his Wife at the Convention Seemed Completely Calculated"*

99.title: Doonesbury
99.author: G
99.series: Oct. 26, 2000) "So Does Cheney Get a Pass on Fibs, Too?"*
notes: Summary: Politicians can get facts wrong if they speak from "a core of long-held convictions."

100.title: Doonesbury
100.author: by Garry Trudeau.
100.series: Nov. 30, 2000) "They Had to Strike During Cocktail Hour, Didn't They"*
notes: Summary: Harvard has "a history of knocking heads during protests." The president has to decide what to do this time.

101.title: Doonesbury
101.author: G
101.series: July 23, 2001) "If Something Happened to Cheney, There'd Still be Someone in Charge"*
notes: Summary: If Dick Cheney has a heart attack, there's Colin Powell or Rumsfeld, though maybe not Bush.

102.title: Doonesbury
102.author: [No author]

contents.author: G.B. Trudeau.
contents.title: Market the Veep's Real-time Cardiac Output!"* (Doonesbury, July 25, 2001)

notes: Summary: Why not sell Dick Cheney's "defib datastream" to "heads of state, brokers and bookies?"

103.title: Doonesbury
103.author: G
103.series: Oct. 1, 2001) "I No Longer Care What Madonna Had for Breakfast!"*
notes: Summary: Things have changed for Boopsie, in response to the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist strikes.

104.title: Doonesbury
104.author: G
104.series: Oct. 2, 2001) "I Want to Be a Firefighter"*
notes: In response to the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist strikes, the grownups care less about celebrities and football, and even the kids think differently.

105.title: Doonesbury
105.author: G
notes: Summary: Boopsie and B.D. talk about the value of their respective occupations (acting and football) in the light of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist strikes.

106.title: Doonesbury
106.author: G
106.series: Oct. 6, 2001) "God Doesn't Condone Suffering and Loss Any More than He Causes it, as Falwell Claimed"*

107.title: Doonesbury
107.author: G
notes: Summary: The President is trying to connect the dots, and sees a puppy.

108.title: Doonesbury
108.author: GB Trudeau.
108.series: June 12, 2002) "But We Bought You Last October! Twice!"*
notes: Summary: Akbari is now with the Taliban.

109.title: Doonesbury
109.author: by Garry Trudeau.
109.series: Aug. 9, 2003) "It's Part of Our New Candor Program"*
notes: Summary: The claim of actual weapons of mass destruction in Iraq has been downgraded to a claim that there was a program for weapons of mass destruction.

110.title: Doonesbury
110.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: A fellow airplane passenger tries to steal Zonker's fiscal plan for his campaign.

111.title: Doonesbury
111.author: GB Trudeau.
111.series: Apr. 12, 2004) "That's Odd, I Didn't Even Know He Had a Girlfriend"*
notes: Summary: There's a necktie on the doorknob.

112.title: Doonesbury
112.author: G
notes: Originally presented in October 2003.
Summary: He's embarrassed to be caught looking at a sex site with his computer. The woman on his screen seems determined.

113.title: Doonesbury
113.author: G
113.series: Apr. 14, 2004) "Well, I Wouldn't Dupe Her Home to Mom"*
notes: Copyright 2003.
Summary: He found his cyberpal Brandee on the Maxim site.

114.title: Doonesbury
114.author: Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: The doctor talks about the grieving process for amputees, and B.D. wakes up angry.

115.title: Doonesbury
115.author: by Garry Trudeau.
115.series: May 4, 2004) "Could I Send My Roommate a Note?"*
notes: Summary: At the class reunion, the ones who oppose Bush and thus hate freedom are on the other side of the tent.

116.title: Doonesbury
116.author: GB Trudeau.
116.series: June 14, 2004) "We Liberate You from Your Little Talibuddies and the First Thing You Do is Re-Trash Your Own Country"*
notes: Summary: Duke wants Akbari to tell him how much Afghan warlords cost these days.

117.title: Doonesbury
117.author: by Garry Trudeau.
117.series: June 30, 2004) "It Was Either That or Special Forces"*
notes: Summary: Zonker talks about his career as part-time nanny, with B.D.'s physiatrist.

118.title: Doonesbury
118.author: by Garry Trudeau.
118.series: July 3, 2004) "Hey, Dude! Don't Let 'em Promote You!"*
notes: Summary: The guy in the other wheelchair is a sergeant named Jason Pepper.

119.title: Doonesbury
119.author: [No author]
119.series: July 2, 2004) "I Thought He Was Just This Random Do-Gooder"*
notes: Summary: Jim comes through the amputee ward handing out milkshakes. Jim is a double amputee.

120.title: Doonesbury
120.author: G
120.series: July 5, 2004) "I Don't Know Anything. It's Much Too Dangerous to Leave the Hotel"*
notes: Summary: Roland Hedley reports live from the chaos of Baghdad.

121.title: Doonesbury
121.author: G
notes: Summary: The "live broadcast" from Baghdad is about taking bodyguards and armored cars to briefings.

122.title: Doonesbury
122.author: G
122.series: July 7, 2004) "When the M.P.'s Found Him, there Wasn't a Scratch on Him!"*
notes: Summary: It's too dangerous to "birddog all the positive stories," so the general tells them about a successful delivery of textbooks to Mosul.

123.title: Doonesbury
123.author: G
123.series: July 8, 2004) "The Coalition is Continuing Offensive Operations to Establish a Stable Iraq"*
notes: Summary: The enemies are "Al Quaeda, the Sadr militia, the Zarqawi network, Baathist insurgents, Hezbollah, the Sunni mujahedien and foreign jihads," plus some dead-enders.

124.title: Doonesbury
124.author: by Garry Trudeau.
124.series: July 10, 2004) "The U.S. is Building Permanent Bases Throughout Iraq"*
notes: Summary: the handover of sovereignty doesn't seem to be the end of the war.

125.title: Doonesbury
125.author: Garry Trudeau.
125.series: July 21, 2004) "Every Day Fox Reporters are Sent Edicts Telling Them What to Say And How to Say It!"*
notes: Summary: Mark Slackmeyer is interviewing Rupert Murdoch.

126.title: Doonesbury
126.author: G
126.series: May 5, 2005) "Fortunately Everyone's Still Psyched about the Elections"*
notes: Summary: Report from the Iraq war, about ambushes, "hillbilly-armored" Humvees, and random mortar rounds.

127.title: Doonesbury
127.author: by Garry Trudeau.
127.series: June 28, 2005) "One Day a Tsunami Will Come and There Will be a Great Reckoning!"*
notes: Summary: The Surfer points out the bulldozers sent by mansion-dwellers.

128.title: Doonesbury
128.author: G
128.series: July 22, 2005) "He Really Shot Up the Garage?"*
notes: Summary: B.D.'s anxious all the time, and the lawnmower wouldn't start.

129.title: Doonesbury
129.author: by Garry Trudeau.
129.series: Sept. 8, 2005) "I Actually Wish We Could Switch Places"*
notes: Summary: B.D. has an e-mail conversation with Ray in Iraq.

130.title: Doonesbury
130.author: Garry Trudeau.
130.series: May 3, 2006) "Who Wants to Start Every Day Getting Over Yourself?"
notes: Summary: The level of self-esteem is a bit too high at Harvard.

131.title: Doonesbury
131.author: by Garry Trudeau.
131.series: May 10, 2006) "Fun Question, Why Do You Ask?"*
notes: Summary: Alex gives the interviewer from Cornell a problem about circuits in black boxes. The answer has to do with resistors and heat.

132.title: Doonesbury
132.author: G
132.series: June 2, 2006) "Suddenly You Want To Hear My Old War Stories?"*
notes: Copyright 2001.

133.title: Doonesbury
133.author: Garry Trudeau.
133.series: Oct. 30, 2006) "Have You Ever Been There? It's Disgusting!"*
notes: Summary: Boopsie objects to both the quantity and quality of the food at McFriendly's, where Zonker works.

134.title: Doonesbury
134.author: Garry Trudeau.
134.series: Nov. 1, 2006) "You Wouldn't Have to Eat Again Until Monday"*
notes: Summary: The "big feed" special at McFriendlys is a great value: 22,000 calories for $89.95.

135.title: Doonesbury
135.author: Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: The customer wants a pitcher of scotch, and has a private meat locker at the restaurant.

136.title: Doonesbury
136.author: by Garry Trudeau.
136.series: Apr. 27, 2007) "Dad Told Me You're Applying for the War Czar Position"*
notes: Summary: Jeff isn't worried, he'll have bodyguards.

137.title: Doonesbury
137.author: by Garry Trudeau.
137.series: Sept. 1, 2007) "I'm from Geeky Stock. My People Like to Study"*
notes: Summary: The recruiter from Walden comes from a hip background.

138.title: Doonesbury
138.author: by Garry Trudeau.
138.series: Sept. 2, 2007) "Don't You Figments All Hang Out Together?"*
notes: Summary: Mark asks the Easter bunny about the "myth of GOP fiscal responsibility."

139.title: Doonesbury
139.author: Garry Trudeau.
139.series: Dec. 16, 2009) "Comedy Writers Fear Layoffs as Nearly 2,000 Tiger Jokes Write Themselves"*
notes: Summary: Tiger Woods' mistresses have voted to unionize.

140.title: Doonesbury
140.author: Garry Trudeau.
140.series: Dec. 17, 2009) "He's One of Golf's Immortals, Right?"*
notes: Summary: Tiger Woods' mistresses are "noctural hospitality workers," so there's a vampire angle.

141.title: Doonesbury
141.author: by Garry Trudeau.
141.series: July 2, 2010) "You Want To Blow Us All Up?"*
notes: Summary: The customers are more worried about tar balls than hair nets, and the boss doesn't want Armando smoking near the crabs.

142.title: Doonesbury
142.author: by Garry Trudeau.
142.series: July 3, 2010) "The Oil Spill has Created this Ridiculous Myth about Threats from the Ocean"*
notes: Summary: "It's like when Jaws came out."

143.title: Doonesbury
143.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Red Rascal, the "lone, fearless cowboy," is going to meet President Karzai.

144.title: Doonesbury
144.author: G
144.series: Sept. 29, 2011) "Did You Know Jesus Turned a Few Loaves and Fishes into Enough Grub for 5,000?"*
notes: Summary: Texas has a high "food insecurity rate", and candidate Perry says that story about Jesus always makes him hungry.

145.title: Doonesbury
145.author: G
notes: Summary: Roz once hit on a married specialist at Fort Hood.

146.title: Doonesbury
146.author: by G
notes: Summary: Walden College has just finished a class reunion on Zoom.

147.title: Doonesbury
147.author: by G
notes: Summary: Demonstrators are being interviewed, about Donald Trump, Covid being a hoax and a liberal disease, and swamp scientists, plus a man without a mask demonstrates "real-time natural selection" by coughing.

148.title: Doonesbury
148.author: by G
148.series: Sept. 27, 2020) "Each Dot in the Following Panels Represents a Single Lost Life"*
notes: Summary: You can count them, over 200,000, or like Donald Trump you can just look away and they're not there.

149.title: Doonesbury
149.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Donald Trump does the math, figuring out how many Americans have not been killed by the coronavirus.

150.title: Doonesbury
150.author: by G
notes: Summary: Nothing sold of J.J.'s big show last Winter, and we see her sculptures all look like coronavirus globes.

151.title: Doonesbury
151.author: by G
151.series: Nov. 22, 2020) ""Last Spring We Even Lost Two Veteran Characters"*
notes: Summary: The strip has lost characters, but not to covid.

152.title: Doonesbury
152.author: by G
152.series: Nov. 29, 2020) "Your Mom Can Fill You In"*
notes: Summary: The youth don't read or watch the news, and don't know what's going on: "what pandemic?"

153.title: Doonesbury
153.author: Garry Trudeau.
153.series: Jan. 12, 2021) "Mike's Annual Summer Daydream is Under Way"*
notes: Summary: Bernie wants Mike to move to Seattle, telecommute, wear flannel shirts, and start at $300,000.
Strip originally appeared July 25, 1995.
